description: (insertimage)The 1527 slave revolt in Puerto Rico stands out in the island's history. Christopher Columbus tried to appease the whites by being harsh on the Africans and Indians; there were many ill-fated revolts, but this one was significant. The rebellion was led by an enslaved African named Guamaní, originally from the Gold Coast (present-day Ghana). Guamaní organized this revolt with a group of enslaved people and the indigenous Taino. They attacked the Spanish settlement of San Germán, killing several colonizers and burning down buildings. The rebels then moved on to attack other settlements in the region. However, the Spanish authorities quickly responded to the rebellion, sending troops to suppress the uprising. The rebels were defeated after several battles; many were captured, forty slaves were shot, and many fled the island. Despite the revolt's failure, it was a powerful symbol of resistance against slavery and oppression. The legacy of Guamaní and the other rebels has inspired subsequent generations of Puerto Ricans to fight for justice and equality. .

description: The 1532 slave revolt in Venezuela was an uprising by enslaved Africans who were brought to the colony by the Spanish to work in the fields and mines. The rebellion was led by an enslaved African named Juan de Bolas, who had been a chieftain in his homeland before being captured and enslaved. During the revolt, Juan de Bolas and his followers attacked and killed Spanish settlers and soldiers, burned down buildings, and seized control of towns and plantations. The rebellion lasted for several months before being brutally suppressed by Spanish forces.The revolt was one of the earliest and most significant slave uprisings in the Americas and is considered a precursor to other slave revolts that would occur in the centuries that followed.

description: There is limited information available about a slave revolt in Santa Marta, Colombia in 1533. However, historical records indicate that there was a rebellion of African slaves against their Spanish masters in the region at that time. According to some sources, the revolt was led by an African slave named Juan de Palomino, who had been brought to Colombia from the Congo. The slaves attacked and burned Spanish settlements and plantations, killing many of their masters. The Spanish authorities eventually crushed the revolt and punished the rebellious slaves harshly. Palomino and other leaders of the revolt were executed, and many other slaves were subjected to brutal torture and punishment. The 1533 slave revolt in Santa Marta was one of the earliest recorded slave uprisings in the Americas, and it demonstrated the deep-seated resentment and resistance that many African slaves felt towards their European masters.
citations: Jeremy D. Popkin, "Resistance and Rebellion in the Early Modern Atlantic World, Routledge, 2017.

description: There is historical evidence of a slave revolt that took place in Cartagena, Colombia, in 1550. A group of enslaved Africans led the rebellion brought to the region by Spanish colonizers to work on sugar plantations and in mines. The rebellion began when a group of slaves, led by an enslaved African named Bayano, escaped from their plantation and fled to the mountains. There, they formed a community of escaped slaves and began to raid Spanish settlements, freeing other enslaved people and attacking their former masters. The rebellion was successful for a time, and the escaped slaves managed to gain control of a large part of the region. However, the Spanish authorities eventually crushed the revolt and captured Bayano and other rebellion leaders. Bayano was executed, and many other slaves were punished harshly, including torture, mutilation, and being burned alive. Despite this, the revolt had a lasting impact on the region, and it helped to inspire other slave rebellions throughout the Americas

description: The 1552 slave revolt in Buria, Venezuela, was one of the earliest and largest slave rebellions in the Americas, lasting over three years. El Negro Miguel led the revolt with a group of enslaved Africans brought to the area to work on sugar plantations. Miguel escaped slavery after the master tried to punish him; he grabbed the sword and fought back. (Insert Image 2) Miguel founded a settlement populated by Africans and Indigenous peoples, called a Cimarrón or Cumbe (escaped slave). He proclaimed himself the King, taking a queen, Guiomar, and establishing draconian rules to maintain order. Due to its location, it became necessary to wage attacks on small farms and plantations to acquire food and supplies. (image 3) Miguel would build an army of up to 1,500 people. The rebellion began on July 26, 1552, and quickly spread throughout the region; the settlement would be sieged with battles throughout his reign. (Image 4) The slaves seized control of several plantations and fought against Spanish troops sent to suppress the rebellion. In 1554, they captured a town, and killed a priest and six others. The revolt's aftermath was brutal, with many slaves being executed or forced to flee into the surrounding wilderness. After the killing of Miguel, many of the enslaved lost hope; most were executed, and the women and children were sent to surrounding plantations. (Images 5 & 6)

description: (Insert Image) Gasper Yanga, a descendant of royalty from Gabon, led a revolt against the Spanish in 1570. There were a series of uprisings between 1540 and 1600 against the Spanish crown, but what distinguishes this one is that it successfully created a settlement of freed Africans, the first one in the Americas, established in 1630. At its peak, there were up to 500 African and Indian settlers in the Maroon that was initially named San Lorenzo de los Negros and renamed Yanga in 1932. The Spanish made many failed attempts to subdue the Africans, leading to a treaty signed in 1608 that held, among other things, that those in the settlement at that time would remain free, but anyone coming after 1608 would be returned to their masters.

There were several uprisings in Mexico, one leading the way for another. In 1611 an African woman was killed from the cruelty of her master. In response, the African Brotherhood, a confraternity of Africans, carried her body in the funeral procession. At this point, rumors began that all white men would be killed and the women kept as concubines. The Spanish responded with harsh restrictions on the Black Mexicans, restricting movement and the ability to assemble. This event became the precursor to the 1612 plot; when munitions were found among the enslaved, the executions began. Thirty-five blacks, including seven women, were publicly hanged in the central plaza of Mexico City for plotting an uprising of enslaved Black people to overthrow Spanish power in Mexico, 24 were beheaded, and some were quartered and their bodies left to rot in the streets (Insert image).

description: In Antigua, the Kaliangos killed fifty white settlers and captured the governor‚Äôs wife and children, destroying their crops and houses. Many other revolts were happening near this event on the islands. Whites in St. Kitts were much alarmed when a band of 60 women revolted in the French Quarter and fled to the hills. Then in November of that same year, more than 60 enslaved Africans from the Capisterre region left their plantations and found refuge on the slopes of Mount Misery. Accompanied by their women and children, they protected themselves by the surrounding environment on a mountainous precipice that a narrow strip of land could only approach. This vantage point enabled them to pillage the plantations of the slaveholders. After a stint of pillaging and destruction, they were eventually overtaken by an army of 500 men who destroyed and disbanded their stronghold. They were killed, punished, and made examples of to eliminate the attempts and actions of future rebellions by other enslaved people.

King Zumba's heir, Zumbi, continued resisting the Portuguese until he was betrayed by a former comrade and killed by the Portuguese.

Under King Zumba, they had many victorious battles against the Portuguese, but later the King signed a treaty with them for the sanctuary of himself and some of the members. Of course, the Portuguese did not honor the agreement, and many Blacks were sold into slavery, and the King was poisoned by one of his own. King Zumba's heir, Zumbi, continued resisting the Portuguese until he was betrayed by a former comrade and killed by the Portuguese.

description: 1665-1709 "In 1661 King Garcia II, died leaving the throne to his second eldest son António.[6] King António I was determined to remove the Portuguese from Angola, as they had been a thorn in Kongo's side since 1622.[7] King Garcia II's gambit of assisting the Dutch in their short war with Portugal over the port of Luanda had turned out badly. description: "The first one was led by Ana de Bengal, the woman slave leader, and it was a massive rebellion in then Dutch colony, Mauritius, which was run from its Cape colony. The rebellion was held on 18 July 1695. Ana de Bengal worked collectively with two other slave colleagues, Antoni de Malabar and Aron de Amboina, as leaders of the uprising. They burnt down the entire colonial headquarters in Mauritius. Although they were publicly executed, this fueled further slave rebellions, which ended up being one of the reasons for the Dutch finally abandoning their Mauritian colony as from 1705."

description: Whites still stunned by the 1708 murder of a white family were very paranoid and sensitive to any sign of a revolt. The plan was launced on Sunday, April 6th as Sabbath was designated by law as a day of worship. The rebels organized and took a blood oath of secrecy and had magic powder sprinkled on themselves as protection from bullets. They set fire to the outhouse and when the whites appeared they attacked and killed 9 whites and injured 7 others. They were captured, six committed suicide rather that go to trial. "Thirty-nine slaves stood trial for murder, witnesses were called to provide testimony, and surprisingly thirteen slaves were acquitted and an additional three slaves were later pardoned. A pregnant rebel had her execution suspended, and Britain's Queen Anne pardoned a slave named Marrs, as well as the Spanish Indians who had participated".

(Image 1) A series of insurrections and runaways in Jamaica led to the first Maroon War from 1720-1739 that ended in a Peace Treaty under Cudjoe and Nanny, leading to the establishment of Maroon Town; however, tensions continued. Planters saw the Maroons as a threat to their existence, giving hope to the still enslaved, and the Africans continued their assault on the Planters. In response, the militia became more aggressive, inciting further violence between the two. Other causes were: encroachment on land allocated to the Maroons; increased interaction between the Marooners and enslaved people, often marrying and having children, thus assisting in their escape. The Planters used these incidents to break the Treaty of 1738, setting the stage for the Second War. (Image 2 & 3)

description: (insert image 1) (insert image 2)The Malagasy Africans were on deck, watching the sailors, looking for signs of weakness. When one left to get a drink, the Africans grabbed an axe, and within seconds the others grabbed unsecured tools in a barrel and armed themselves with shackles and cannon balls from another barrel. One sailor who noticed the insurrection was killed right away; a few Africans who hadn't had their ankle irons locked could attack others (insert image 4). It took the Malagasy only a few minutes to seize the deck as the crew was not prepared to deal with this revolt, nor did they have access to weapons. The commotion got the attention of a ship nearby, the Alcyon, that tried to subdue the ship by firing a cannon and then sailing on small boats close to the ship, but the Africans found guns and shot at them (insert image 3). As the Vautour ran aground, many Africans jumped overboard; the French shot some on the Alcyon, but the other survivors ran away. The Vautour was beyond repair. This event limited the number of Africans taken from this country; this successful African mutiny on the French vessel the Vautour precipitated other insurrections.

description: 1725-40 (circa) The Windward Maroons were led by Nanny and the Leeward Maroons were led by Cudjoe. Nanny ruled as an African Queen and an Obeah Woman and carried on African culture and traditions amongst her people. When there was fighting the women and children under her protection would hide in 'Girls' Town' or 'Women's Town' in the John Crow Mountains. Nanny made a vow on Pumpkin Hill in 1737 to fight the British to death. When she did sign the treaty with the British she was wearing the teeth of her dead British enemies. She established Nanny Town which is still in existence. In 1977 she was awarded the posthumous honour of 'National Heroine'.

description: The Great Natchez Massacre in 1729 was one of many occurrences where Africans aligned with the Indigenous in battling Europeans. This attack erupted after failed negotiations between the Natchez and the French and their encroachment on sacred land. During the assault, the Natchez freed the enslaved people in hopes of inciting an insurrection. The combined force attacked a French settlement and killed approximately 200 of them, freed 275 enslaved people, leading to an established Maroon community in Mississippi. Despite their fear of an alliance between Africans and Indigenous people, the French were the first to arm the African captives. They conquered the Natchez with support from the Choctaw, Tunica, and Pro-French Natchez in 1730. When the Spanish took over the area, they abolished Indigenous slavery in 1763, leading to increased African enslavement.(Insert image 3, 1, & 2)

description: Jamaica was first held by the Spanish who were defeated by the British. The Spanish left their enslaved populations on the island , many of whom had fled to the mountains of the country. There were two major maroon groups totaling in the several thousands. The leeward group was led by Cudjoe and his brothers Accompong and Johnny. The other group, the Windwards was led by Cuffee, Quao, Kishee and the infamous female leader Nanny. The struggle with the British lasted well over nine years with the British conceding to negotiations. The British even used armed Blacks called "Blackshots" but many of them wound up negotiating with the Maroons and supplying them with munitions. The Maroon populations not only fought the British but frequently attacked European settlements for arms and rations. The negotiations gave land to the Maroon popuation if they agreed to return runaway slaves to the British, they also wanted to be repatriated to West Africa but were not allowed to return. Mark G. Jaede in Encyclopedia of Slave Resistance and Rebellion, Junius Rodriguez ,eds. Greenwood Press: 2006, pp. 195-197.

description: Samba Rebellion is the name given to a slave conspiracy that is alleged to have occurred in eastern Louisiana, although surviving official records do not support the story, tales of the plot appear in popular historical accounts. This rebellion was led by the Bambaras from Senegal and The Gambia spurred on from the Natchez and French Uprising of 1729. Planned for June of 1731, the insurrection was to kill the whites and set up a new government manned by Barbaras who would maintain slavery. The plan was leaked and Samba, seven other men and one woman were executed in Place d'Armes (Jackson Square).

description: (Image 1) The revolt in St. John, also known as the Akwamu Revolt, was one of the longest-lasting rebellions led by an identifiable ethnic group, the Amina from the Gold Coast of Africa, whose goal was to take over the island and maintain slave production under their rule. (Image 2)There were events leading up to the revolt of natural disasters: (Image 3) a drought; infestation that led to the destruction of crops and starvation. More stringent controls were enforced to prevent the Africans from running away, leading to the eventual revolt. Most whites fled the island, particularly those their loyal Blacks warned. (Image 4) The Dutch elicited the support of the British colonies from Tortola and St. Kitts to quell the revolt. Still, they were unsuccessful-it was the role of the Free Negro Corps infantry in combination with the French that led to their defeat. Ultimately, over 48 plantations out of 92 were destroyed-killing 87 Blacks and 29 whites. The French implored the leader to surrender, and a deal would ensue; however, as soon as he did, he was murdered. Other rebels committed suicide rather than face capture. (Images 5 & 6)

description: The Stono Rebellion, also known as the Stono Revolt, was one of the largest slave uprisings in colonial America in the British colony of South Carolina on September 9, 1739. (Image 1) The rebellion began when a group of about 20 enslaved Africans, led by Jemmy, from Angola/Congo, gathered near the Stono River, south of Charleston, and stole weapons from a store. (Image 2) They then marched south towards Florida, where they hoped to find freedom, beating drums, and shouting "liberty!" along the way, and recruited other slaves to join them. As they marched, others joined them, with their number swelling to over 100. The rebels' ultimate goal was to reach Spanish Florida, where they hoped to find freedom, as the Spanish were known for offering asylum to slaves who escaped from the British colonies.(Image 3) They burned plantations and decapitated a few whites and left their heads on the porch. One slave hid his master, and another alerted his of the revolt, both were rewarded with their freedom. When they arrived at the Edisto bridge, they stopped and performed a war dance that led to their demise as they were shot down. A group of white settlers and soldiers near the Edisto River intercepted them, A battle ensued, and most rebels were killed. the South Carolina militia eventually suppressed the rebellion. In the end some twenty-five whites were killed before the insurrection was put down. At its height, approximately 150-200 enslaved were involved, sixty-five of them died. Those who captured were executed or sold into slavery in the West Indies. The aftermath was stricter slave codes and harsher treatment of slaves in the South; it also served as a reminder of the constant threat of slave uprisings and fueled fears of insurrection among white plantation owners. (Image 4)

description: Francois Makandal was a notorious Maroon leader who's goal was to use his base to kill all the whites. He was an educated Muslim and religious leader from West Africa and was captured as a prisoner of war and sold into slavery. Francois Mackandal was enslaved at the age of 12, after losing his hand in processing sugar cane he was assigned to care for the livestock. He escaped from a plantation around 1740 and escaped to the Maroon community where he organized the Maroons to attack the French in a series of battles. He could not get support of the Mulattos to purchase munitions so he used his extensive knowledge of plants to conjure up poisons that was used to kill whites, livestock and other slaves and killed approximately six thousand people within three years. His ultimate plan was to poison the water systems and attack the city. He said he, "... was sent by God to Santo Domingue to destroy the whites and free the Blacks." The Irish presence in Montserrat dates back to the 1630s when the first pioneers- Roman Catholics - sailed over from Saint Kitts because of friction with British protestant settlers there. The Irish planters brought enslaved Africans to work the sugarcane fields, who soon outnumbered them 3 to 1. Other Irish immigrants were initially deported to the islands by the British as indentured workers on sugar and tobacco plantations and could work their way into eventually becoming landowners. 70% of all white citizens on the island claimed to be of Irish heritage and celebrate St. Patrick‚Äôs Day with the same spirit of gluttony and vitality. In 1768, the enslaved planned an uprising on that holiday, when the planters were celebrating, hoping their Irish overseers would be too drunk to interfere. The holiday seemed a prime opportunity for a revolt: Cudjo, the leader, spent months devising the plan where they were instructed to grab all the weapons they could find inside the government house while the Irish slept and storm the building with rocks, farm tools, clubs, and homemade swords. Revolt details leaked by a female enabled the Irish to ready themselves for the attack by not consuming alcohol. Nine plan developers, including Cudjo, were hung, and others were convicted and shipped off to other islands. Today people mix their annual celebration of shamrocks and green beer with memories of the enslaved African revolt against Irish planters. Montserratians commemorate the day with a Masquerade, where islanders dance the Irish jigs one night, then mock their one-time masters the next by cracking whips while dressed in tall hats like bishops‚Äô miters.

description: (image 1) The 1789 Slave revolt in Guadeloupe was a significant event in the island's history. The revolt began on August 20, 1789, when a group of enslaved Africans rose up against the plantation owners and the French colonial government. The spark that ignited the revolt was the news of the French Revolution, which had begun earlier that year and inspired the enslaved Africans to demand their freedom. African people had an Underground communication system that informed them of the international wars and their impact on slavery. Some whites went as far as to spell words so Africans couldn't know, but they translated the letters. The rebels managed to take control of several towns and plantations on the island, and for a brief period, it seemed that they might succeed in overthrowing the colonial government. However, the French authorities eventually sent troops to suppress the revolt, and after several weeks of fighting, the rebels were defeated. The aftermath of the revolt was brutal. Many rebels were executed, and hundreds of others were sold to plantations in other colonies. However, the rebellion did have a significant impact on the fight against slavery in the French Empire, as it helped to bring the issue to the forefront of public debate and contributed to the eventual abolition of slavery in France and its colonies in the 19th century. description: The slave rebellion of trois rivie'res illustrates the tenuous yet strategic position of the the free Blacks in Martinique, Guadeloupe and Haiti or Lesser Antilles, also known as the gens de couleur. this group was basically heterogeneous, some were very rich that led to their alliances with white planters and others were poor farmers. The French Revolution opened the question of the equal status of free Blacks. Some political forces wanted the gens de couleur to be equal because they were a major force in suppressing slave revolts; however, that designation threatened the hierarchy of white domination and superiority. This conundrum is going to play out in many ways that will ultimately lead to the abolition of slavery. The gens de couleur would form different alliances based on what they viewed as advantageous to themselves, leading the enslaved into supporting their campaigns under the pretense of being pro-abolitionists, some were ,some weren't. This battle involved thousands of slaves, led by those who declared themselves "citizens", when met by the French they proclaimed they "...had killed masters who had tried to arm them against the patriots, (and) forcibly integrated themselves into the Republic", they were then left alone to continue their armed campaign.

description: Tula, also known as Tula Rigaud, was an African man enslaved on the island of Curaçao, in the Dutch West Indies, who liberated himself and led the Curaçao Slave Revolt of 1795 with the assistance of another enslaved man and a woman. They traveled through the island gathering other enslaved people from surroundinig plantations and marched through the island destroying property and lives. The revolt, which began on 17 August 1795, lasted for more than a month. He was executed on 3 October 1795. This rebellion was precipitated from the harsh conditions the enslaved were under to increase productivity, certain privileges that had been granted were withdrawn like no work on Sundays. In addition, the Black network had information on the revolt in Haiti and also the defeat of the Dutch by the French and it was hoped that reforms made in the Batavian Republic would come to Curacao and abolish slavery. Tula led a month long rebellion along with another man and woman They traveled across the island gathering up many enslaved to assist that swelled up to 1,000-they demanded end to collective punishment; no work on Sunday and ability to buy clothes and other supplies outside their plantation and later freedom. Negotiations broke down and they were suppressed, Tula was publicly executed. The revolt was led by Tula, Bastiaan Carpata and a woman and lasted one month, until suppressed by the "Corps of Free Coloreds and Blacks in the field..." The revolt began on one plantation where about fifty slaves refused to work, they then traveled to other plantations recruiting like-minded enslaved.

description: Gabriel Prosser's life and planned insurrection highlights the contradictions and nuances of slavery. Garbriel was literate and a skilled Blacksmith, probably a skill he learned from his father. Although well acquainted with Christianity and the bible, he did not become a minister. His skills afforded him the ability to be hired out in Richmond, Virginia. Gabriel was informed by the politics of the day, the discontent between the political parties and the aftermath of the French Revolution with the calls of equality, fraternity and democracy. Prosser chose a Saturday as a large number of Blacks going into town would not alert the slave patrollers. HIs plan was to organize free and enslaved Blacks, "...march on Richmond under a flag reading 'Death or Liberty'", seize the city's armory and force the planters to release their slaves. It rained that day so the revolt was postponed to the next day, long enough for one of the slaves to change his mind and alert the officials. Twenty-seven Blacks were executed including Gabriel's two brothers.

Solitude had convinced her people to join with Degrés. They lured the French into a fort, where they were cornered, and set off gunpowder, killing themselves and 400 French soldiers. Under Napoleon, approximately 10,000 Guadeloupeans lost their lives before the abolition of slavery in 1848. Solitude survived the ambush and was later tried and convicted. The French executed her the day after her baby was born and became her owner's property!

description: (Insert image) "The British invasion of the Río de la Plata of 1806 followed an uprising of Argentine's slave population in Buenos Aires encouraged by the rise of the movement for abolition of slavery in Britain. Afro-Argentines believed that the British expedition came mainly to give them their independence, but the British general, William Carr Beresford, had no sympathy with this movement. The spokesman for the Creoles in Buenos Aires, Juan Martín de Pueyrredón argued that the region's economic base would be ruined if slavery were immediately abolished. He demanded action on behalf of their estates; General Beresford announced that slaves would not be freed, and Pueyrredón said "they were stopped in time" ("se los atajó a tiempo") in July 1806, in a letter to his father-in-law in Cádiz.[citation needed] This measure contributed to the defeat of the British invasion, because it drove the slaves to fight against them."

description: Plans for the revolt were leaked by a "loyal slave to his master". This rebellion was planned by Hausa and Male,' both slave and free, by those residing in one of the Quilombos. There were a number of factors: there were class conflicts in Portugal that led to popular revolts that spilled in to Brazil that wanted local autonomy. Inspite of the demand for sugar, there was severe poverty caused by droughts; and enslavement with wide wealth disparities that increased the cost of living. The African slaves suffered from harsher working conditions and food shortages there was also class (and color) divisions within the free people of color population. Life in the Quilombos provided the Africans a space to practice their traditional culture and honor their ancestral deities. The government ordered attacks on these communities to deter any rebellious activites and instill a "sense of obedience and deference toward their owners and to whites in general" The government raids uncovered a number of weapons among the rebels. There was "An intricate secret organization...with a "captain" in every Parish of he city and an overall commandor..."Eleven individuals involved were punished with 150 lashes followed by a banning of all assemblies and restriction of movement.

description: The 1821 Xiorro Conspiracy was a failed attempt to overthrow Spanish colonial rule in Puerto Rico. The conspiracy was led by a black slave named Marcos Xiorro, a member of the militia in the city of San Juan who planned a plot against the enslavers in the government of Puerto Rico. The plan was that several enslaved people were to escape from various plantations and on themselves with daggers and swords that were hidden in the fields(insert image 1). Xiorro and his followers planned to take over the city and declare independence from Spain. They had scheduled to launch their revolt on Easter Sunday of 1821 to capture and burn the Bayamo town and kill everyone who was not black. After that, they would unite with slaves from joining towns and invade the capital of San Juan to declare Xiorro as their king ( insert image 2). A Royal slave divulged the plans in exchange for 500 pesos and his freedom. The Mayor mobilized 500 soldiers; Xiorro and several other conspirators were arrested and charged with sedition and conspiracy. A total of 61 enslaved people were imprisoned, 17 were punished, and Xiorro was sentenced to death by hanging and publicly executed in San Juan on June 8, 1824. (insert image 3).

description: On Easter Sunday,1822, a slave rebellion occurred on the Plein Palais Estate because of the harsh working conditions. The slaves demanded a three-day holiday and enquired when they would be set free (insert image 1); the manager refused to assure them, so they set the estate on fire. The rebellion was led by Emmanuel, an enslaved laborer on a plantation in the island's southern region. Emmanuel and his followers launched a coordinated attack on several plantations in the area using machetes, axes, and other makeshift weapons to attack their oppressors and seize control of the estates. The rebellion was initially successful, and the rebels held off British troops for several days. However, the British eventually regrouped and launched a counterattack, using their superior firepower to crush the uprising. "Many died from the raging flames, and others were shot when the militia appeared on the scene..." (insert image 2) Emmanuel and several other rebellion leaders were captured and executed, while many other rebels were punished severely. "Three of the leaders were beheaded with an axe in Woodford Square. (insert image 3) Their bodies hung in chains on the various estates where slave societies existed, while the heads remained exposed in the Square. It took four years to crush the remnants of the rebellion." (insert image 4) The revolt's aftermath led to even harsher treatment of enslaved Africans on the island.

description: ‚Äé In June 1825 the Cuban countryside witnessed a large African-led slave rebellion -- a revolt that began a cycle of slave uprisings lasting until the mid-1840s. Unlike previous slave revolts -- led by alliances between free people of color and slaves, blacks and mulattoes, Africans and Creoles, and rural and urban populations -- only African-born men organized the uprising of 1825. description: Nat Turner revolt is the most well known of all. At the height of the revolt, 50 slaves were involved as they traveled from plantation to plantation killing approximately 60 men, women and children mostly through decapitation. As they made their way to Jerusalem the recruits wanted to rest and disbanded it was this uncalculated move that gave the local militias the opportunity to attack. Nat's band had decreased to no more than thirty where they stopped to rest, the next morning they attacked Belmont where the rest of Turner's force was dispersed. Nat Turner found himself alone and retuned to the Travis plantation where the rebellion began-it took two months for the authorities to locate him, he was hanged and skinned. (the skins of Black people were used to make book covers, belts and wallets-also used as souvenirs) In retaliation, over 200 Blacks were killed, many had never even heard of Nat Turner. As a result, petitions to end slavery poured into the Virginia legislature instead of abolition the "lawmakers passed harsher laws making the lives of the slaves even worst"

description: (Image 1) Africans on the Matanzas plantation revolted and were joined by others at neighboring plantations; up to 250 participated was one of the largest and most significant slave uprisings in Cuban history. The Matanzas plantation was located in the western part of Cuba and was known for its brutal treatment of slaves. The revolt was led by a slave named Juan Francisco Manzano, a poet, and a literate slave. He was able to organize a group of slaves and plan a rebellion against their masters. The slaves were able to seize control of the plantation and hold off the Spanish authorities for several weeks. The Spanish army eventually put down the rebellion, but not before the slaves had caused significant damage to the plantation and killed several of their masters. Juan Francisco Manzano was captured and imprisoned but eventually escaped to the United States, where he became a permanent abolitionist. Officials tried to keep other Africans from finding out, particularly the railroad workers, but they did, and the crowd swelled. In the end, over 100 Africans were killed, eight were shot, and their heads were put on spikes to deter others.

description: (Image 1) LADDER REVOLT Year of the Lash (in Spanish, Año del Cuero) is a term used in Cuba in reference to June 29, 1844, when a firing squad in Havana executed accused leaders of the Conspiración de La Escalera, an alleged slave revolt and movement to abolish slavery in Cuba. The rumor of conspiracies was also directed to rebelling against Spanish rule, precipitating societal repression by the Spanish authorities. Africans took advantage of Spanish rule's political instability and destroyed countless properties. The Spanish authorities brutally suppressed the rebellion who executed hundreds of rebels and suspected sympathizers. The term "Year of the Lash" generally refers to the harsh response toward the would-be uprising by Cuban authorities. Thousands of Afro-Cubans (both slave and free) were executed, imprisoned, or banished from the island. The targeted leaders of the conspiracies were primarily artists, politically astute persons, and artisans, including carpenters, blacksmiths, and shoemakers, who had some degree of education and social mobility. La Escalera (the ladder) alludes to the fact that slave suspects were bound to ladders and whipped with the lash when they were interrogated.

description: Slavery had technically ended in the British colonies in 1834 but was followed by a system of Apprenticeship where the formerly enslaved had to work for depressed wages, secure resources that were provided under slavery and engage in the same type of labor from slavery. Many left the plantations and settled their own farms or merchant enterprises. The Morant Bay Rebellion was initiated by a group of Afro-Jamaicans who had been freed from slavery in the 1830's and had settled on land owned by a white. Litigation ensued and the Afro-Jamaicans were told they had to bear the court costs. Enraged, they returned to the land in question and squatted. Reverend Paul Bogle got involved in the protest, that led to the courthouse being burned down and the looting of properties. Hysteria from previous revolts loomed so what began "...as a local protest concerning taxes and larceny resulted in the death of 350 toilers, the executions of Paul Bogle and George William Gordon on charges of sedition and the termination of local government.
citations: John W. Pulis in Encyclopedia of Slave Resistance and Rebellion, Junius Rodriguez ,eds. Greenwood Press: 2006:, pp. 331-333.

description: (Image 1) "In 1840, Sultan Sayyid Said moved his capital from Arabia to Zanzibar and made it the largest slave market in East Africa, exporting an estimated seventy thousand Africans annually during the 1860s...With plantation-enslaved people comprising more than 50 percent of the islands' populations...these islands became true slave societies. (Image 2) Major slave rebellions broke out on both islands (Pemba)...and were quickly suppressed." (Image 3) In 1873, an enslaved man named Hemedi bin Abdallah and his followers led a revolt in which they attacked their Arab enslavers and seized control of Stone Town in Zanzibar. They then marched to other parts of the island, freeing slaves, and killing planters. The revolt then spread to Pemba, where slaves rose against the Arabs. The rebels captured several towns and villages and established their own government. The British, who had a protectorate over Zanzibar, intervened to abolish the revolt. They bombarded the rebels with artillery and eventually defeated them. Hemedi was captured and executed, along with several other rebel leaders. The rebellion also inspired other slave uprisings in East Africa and contributed to the eventual abolition of slavery in the region.(Image 4)

description: The Third Anglo-Ashanti War, also known as the "First Ashanti Expedition", lasted from 1873 to 1874. 2,500 British troops and several thousand West Indian and African troops (including some Fante) were sent in against the Ashanti. They demolished the royal palace with explosives, leaving Kumasi a heap of smouldering ruins. The British were impressed by the size of the palace and the scope of its contents, including "rows of books in many languages. The Asantahene, the ruler of the Ashanti, signed the harsh Treaty of Fomena in July 1874 to end the war, promising to pay the sum of 50,000 ounces of approved gold as indemnity for the expenses he has occasioned to Her Majesty the Queen of England by the late war..." The Emancipation rebellion of Western Jamaica. This was the largest rebellion in the British West Indies involving some 20,000 slaves and was lead by Sam Sharpe whose main plan was a 'General Strike' against slavery. If the demands of the strike were not met then there was to be military and arson attacks. 'An extensive and destructive insurrection' broke out in the Western District. The Great House and sugar works at Kensington Estate in St. James were set on fire. Other arson attacks on plantations followed. 201 rebels were killed in fighting the combined forces of the British army, navy and local militia. Some 750 slaves and 14 free persons were put on trial and convicted to death or severe flogging (200 - 500 lashes). 21 were transported. When Sharpe was waiting to be executed (May, 23rd, 1832) he said, "I would rather die upon yonder gallows than live in slavery!"
